templates.value:
[[PatientInfo(PatientID,HosID,DOB,Gender,JoinDate,MStatus,InsType)]][[LabEvents(LabItm,LabEvnts,LabEvnts,LabEvnts,Dia,LabelItem,LabelItem1,LabelItem2,LabelItem3,LabelItem4)]]

Microbiological Test Results and Antibiotic Susceptibility:

[[Microbiology(Micro)]]

We hope that this information has helped you understand your medical condition better. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to ask your healthcare provider.

#define PatientInfo(patientId,hospitalId,dob,gender,joindate,martialstatus,Instype)[["

Patient ID: [[patientId]]                 Date of Birth: [[dob]]

Hospital ID: [[numberFormat(hospitalId,'#######')]]              Gender: [[gender]]

The patient was admitted to the hospital on [[JoinDate]]. Upon Admission, it is noted that the patient is [[lower(martialstatus)]] and has a [[Instype]] insurance coverage. The patient's symptoms and medical condition have been noted, and the doctors have prescribed a few tests to ensure an accurate diagnosis. To determine an accurate diagnosis, your doctors ordered several diagnostic tests to better understand your medical condition and symptoms. We know that medical terminology can be overwhelming, so we want to explain the results of your tests in a way that is easy to understand."]]

#define LabEvents(name,value,measure,status,condition,label,label1,label2,label3,label4)

[["We would like to inform you that some of the test results indicated abnormal levels. It is important to note that these abnormal results may be indicative of an underlying health issue that requires further investigation and treatment,

1.[[LabelItem]] - [[ValueNo1]][[MeasureVal1]] : [[LabelEvent(value,label)]]

2.[[LabelItem1]] - [[ValueNo2]][[MeasureVal2]] : [[LabelEvent01(value,label1)]] 

3.[[LabelItem2]] - [[ValueNo3]][[MeasureVal3]] : [[LabelEvent02(value,label2)]] 

4.[[LabelItem3]] - [[ValueNo4]][[MeasureVal4]] : [[LabelEvent03(value,label3)]] 

5.[[LabelItem4]] - [[ValueNo5]][[MeasureVal5]] : [[LabelEvent04(value,label4)]]"

]]

#value Microbiology(name)[[

"In addition to the diagnostic tests, the patient was advised to take some microbiological tests. These tests involved analyzing samples of your bodily fluids, such as blood or urine, to detect the presence of harmful bacteria. The results of these tests revealed that you have an infection caused by [[ myList= (MicroOrg1,MicroOrg2,MicroOrg3,MicroOrg4,MicroOrg5) 

unique(myList)]].

To effectively treat your infection, the samples were tested with various antibiotics, to know which one would be the most effective against the bacteria. This process, called antibiotic susceptibility testing, helps to determine which antibiotics will be most effective in treating the infection. The antibiotics that were tested for your specific case include [[titleCase(AntiBody1,true)]], [[titleCase(AntiBody2,true)]], [[titleCase(AntiBody3,true)]], [[titleCase(AntiBody4,true)]] and [[titleCase(AntiBody5,true)]]. It is essential to note that not all antibiotics are effective against every type of infection. Therefore, identifying the right antibiotic is crucial in effectively treating the infection and ensuring a speedy recovery."]]

#value LabelEvent(value,label)

[[if(LabelItem=='MCV'){MCV(Mean Corpuscular Volume) is a measure of the average size of red blood cells in the body. A normal MCV range is typically between 80 and 96 fL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] fL is within the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem=='RDW'){RDW is a measure of the variation in size of red blood cells in the body. A normal RDW range is typically between 11.5% and 14.5%. A value of [[ValueNo1]]% is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a number of medical conditions, such as anemia, liver disease, or vitamin B12 deficiency.}elseif(LabelItem=='Vancomycin'){Vancomycin is an antibiotic that is commonly used to treat bacterial infections. The level of vancomycin in the blood can be measured to determine if the dosage is appropriate and to avoid toxicity. A therapeutic range for vancomycin is typically between 15 and 20 mcg/mL, depending on the type of infection being treated.}elseif(LabelItem=='Lymphocytes'){Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that are important for fighting infections. A normal lymphocyte range is typically between 20% and 40% of total white blood cells. A value of [[ValueNo1]]% is not within the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem=='Glucose'){Glucose is a sugar that the body uses for energy. A normal fasting blood glucose level is between 70 and 99 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate prediabetes or diabetes.}elseif(LabelItem=='Calcium, Total'){Calcium is a mineral that is important for strong bones and teeth, as well as for normal heart, nerve, and muscle function. A normal total calcium level is between 8.5 and 10.2 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as hypoparathyroidism or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Red Blood Cells'){Red blood cells are the most common type of blood cell and are responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body. A normal red blood cell count ranges between 4.5 and 5.5 million/uL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] million/uL is below the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem=='Urobilinogen'){Urobilinogen is a byproduct of the breakdown of hemoglobin in the liver and is excreted in the urine. A normal urobilinogen level is between 0.2 and 1.0 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate liver disease, hemolytic anemia, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='Hematocrit'){Hematocrit is a measure of the percentage of red blood cells in the blood. A normal hematocrit level is between 38 and 52% for men and between 35 and 47% for women. A value of [[ValueNo1]]% is not in the normal range and may indicate anemia or blood loss.}elseif(LabelItem=='MCH'){MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is a measure of the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. A normal MCH level is between 27 and 33 pg. A value of [[ValueNo1]] pg is not in the normal range and may indicate iron deficiency anemia or other medical conditions}elseif(LabelItem=='Hemoglobin'){Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. A normal hemoglobin level is between 13.5 and 17.5 g/dL for men and between 12.0 and 15.5 g/dL for women. A value of [[ValueNo1]] g/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate anemia or blood loss.}elseif(LabelItem=='Troponin T'){Troponin T is a protein that is released into the bloodstream when there is damage to the heart muscle. A normal troponin T level is below 0.03 ng/mL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] ng/mL is not in the normal range and may indicate a heart attack or other heart-related conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='pO2'){pO2 is a measure of the pressure of oxygen in arterial blood. A normal pO2 level is between 75 and 100 mmHg. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mmHg is not in the normal range and may indicate lung disease, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)}elseif(LabelItem=='pH'){pH is a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of the blood. A normal pH level is between 7.35 and 7.45. A value of [[ValueNo1]] is not in the normal range and may indicate respiratory or metabolic acidosis.}elseif(LabelItem=='Urea Nitrogen'){Urea nitrogen is a waste product that is produced in the liver and excreted by the kidneys. A normal urea nitrogen level is between 7 and 20 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate kidney disease or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='Neutrophils'){Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that help fight off infections. A normal percentage of neutrophils in the blood is between 40% and 60%. A value of [[ValueNo1]]% is not in the normal range and may indicate an infection, inflammation, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='PT'){PT stands for prothrombin time, which is a blood test that measures the time it takes for blood to clot. A normal PT range is between 11 and 13.5 seconds. A value of [[ValueNo1]] seconds is not in the normal range and may indicate a blood clotting disorder or liver disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Chloride'){Chloride is an electrolyte that helps regulate the balance of fluids and acid-base in the body. A normal chloride level is between 96 and 106 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as vomiting, diarrhea, or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Amylase'){Amylase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas that helps break down carbohydrates. A normal amylase level is between 25 and 125 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate pancreatitis or other pancreatic disorders.}elseif(LabelItem=='White Blood Cells'){White blood cells are a type of blood cell that help the body fight off infections. A normal range of white blood cells is between 4,000 and 11,000/mm3. A value of [[ValueNo1]]/mm3 is not in the recommended level and may indicate an infection or inflammation.}elseif(LabelItem=='Magnesium'){Magnesium is a mineral that is important for muscle and nerve function, as well as for maintaining heart health. A normal magnesium level is between 1.8 and 2.4 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may cause certain medical conditions, such as malnutrition, alcoholism, or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Creatinine'){Creatinine is a waste product produced by muscles and is filtered out of the blood by the kidneys. A normal creatinine level is between 0.6 and 1.2 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate kidney dysfunction or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='Bicarbonate'){Bicarbonate is an electrolyte that helps regulate the pH of the blood. A normal bicarbonate level is between 22 and 28 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate metabolic acidosis, which can be caused by certain medical conditions, such as kidney disease or diabetes.}elseif(LabelItem=='Potassium'){Potassium is an electrolyte that is essential for proper muscle and nerve function, as well as for regulating the heartbeat. A normal potassium level is between 3.5 and 5.0 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as kidney disease, vomiting, diarrhea, or the use of certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem=='Calculated Total CO2'){Total CO2 (carbon dioxide) is a measurement of the amount of bicarbonate in the blood, which helps to regulate the body's pH balance. A normal total CO2 level is between 22 and 29 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate respiratory or metabolic acidosis.}elseif(LabelItem=='Phosphate'){Phosphate is a mineral that is important for bone health, energy production, and many other bodily functions. A normal phosphate level is between 2.5 and 4.5 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as kidney disease, malnutrition, or hyperparathyroidism.}elseif(LabelItem=='PTT'){PTT (partial thromboplastin time) is a blood test that measures the time it takes for blood to clot. A normal PTT range is typically between 25 and 35 seconds. A value of [[ValueNo1]] seconds is not in the recommended level and may indicate a bleeding disorder or the use of blood-thinning medications.}elseif(LabelItem=='MCHC'){MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is a measure of the concentration of hemoglobin in the red blood cells. A normal MCHC range is typically between 32 and 36 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] g/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate anemia or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='Lactate Dehydrogenase (LD)'){LD is an enzyme that is found in many organs and tissues in the body. An LD test can help diagnose a variety of medical conditions, such as liver or heart disease, anemia, or cancer. A normal LD level is typically between 105 and 333 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate tissue damage or disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Protein, Total'){Total protein is a measurement of the total amount of protein in the blood. A normal total protein level is between 6.0 and 8.3 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] g/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as liver or kidney disease, malnutrition, or certain cancers.}elseif(LabelItem=='Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)'){ALT is an enzyme that is found primarily in the liver. An ALT test can help diagnose liver disease or damage. A normal ALT level is typically between 7 and 56 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate liver disease or damage.}elseif(LabelItem=='Albumin'){Albumin is a protein produced by the liver and is an important component of blood. A normal albumin level is between 3.4 and 5.4 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]]g/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by liver disease, kidney disease, malnutrition, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem=='Sodium'){Sodium is an electrolyte that helps regulate the body's fluid balance and is important for normal muscle and nerve function. A normal sodium level is between 135 and 145 mmol/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mmol/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by dehydration, certain medications, or medical conditions such as Addison's disease or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Platelet Count'){Platelets are blood cells that help with clotting and preventing bleeding. A normal platelet count is between 150,000 and 450,000/mm3. A value of [[ValueNo1]] /mm3 is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as bone marrow disorders, viral infections, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem=='Lipase'){Lipase is an enzyme that helps break down fats in the body. A normal lipase level is between 10 and 140 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as pancreatitis, gallbladder disease, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem=='Alkaline Phosphatase'){Alkaline phosphatase is an enzyme that is important for bone and liver health. A normal alkaline phosphatase level is between 44 and 147 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as liver or bone disease, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem=='Macrophage'){Macrophages are a type of white blood cell that help the body fight infection and inflammation. A normal macrophage percentage is less than 8%. A value of [[ValueNo1]] % or higher may indicate an infection or other medical condition.}elseif(LabelItem=='Lactate'){Lactate is a waste product produced by the body during exercise or when there is not enough oxygen in the blood. A normal lactate level is less than 2 mmol/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mmol/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate a medical emergency such as sepsis, shock, or heart failure.}elseif(LabelItem=='Myelocytes'){Myelocytes are immature white blood cells that are produced in the bone marrow. A normal myelocyte percentage is less than 3%. A value of [[ValueNo1]] % or higher may indicate certain medical conditions, such as leukemia or other bone marrow disorders.}elseif(LabelItem=='Haptoglobin'){Haptoglobin is a protein that helps bind and remove hemoglobin from the blood. A normal haptoglobin level is between 30 and 200 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as hemolytic anemia or liver disease.}elseif(LabelItem=='Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST)'){AST is an enzyme that is important for liver and muscle function. A normal AST level is between 10 and 40 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo1]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as liver disease or muscle damage.}elseif(LabelItem=='pCO2'){pCO2 is the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood and is an important indicator of respiratory function. A normal pCO2 level is between 35 and 45 mmHg. A value of [[ValueNo1]] mmHg is not in the recommended level and may indicate respiratory acidosis, which can be caused by conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, or asthma.}else{The test result is inaccurate, due to Instrumental error.}]]

#value LabelEvent02(value,label2)

[[if(LabelItem2=='MCV'){MCV(Mean Corpuscular Volume) is a measure of the average size of red blood cells in the body. A normal MCV range is typically between 80 and 96 fL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] fL is within the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem2=='RDW'){RDW is a measure of the variation in size of red blood cells in the body. A normal RDW range is typically between 11.5% and 14.5%. A value of [[ValueNo3]]% is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a number of medical conditions, such as anemia, liver disease, or vitamin B12 deficiency.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Vancomycin'){Vancomycin is an antibiotic that is commonly used to treat bacterial infections. The level of vancomycin in the blood can be measured to determine if the dosage is appropriate and to avoid toxicity. A therapeutic range for vancomycin is typically between 15 and 20 mcg/mL, depending on the type of infection being treated.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Lymphocytes'){Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that are important for fighting infections. A normal lymphocyte range is typically between 20% and 40% of total white blood cells. A value of [[ValueNo3]]% is not within the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Glucose'){Glucose is a sugar that the body uses for energy. A normal fasting blood glucose level is between 70 and 99 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate prediabetes or diabetes.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Calcium, Total'){Calcium is a mineral that is important for strong bones and teeth, as well as for normal heart, nerve, and muscle function. A normal total calcium level is between 8.5 and 10.2 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as hypoparathyroidism or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Red Blood Cells'){Red blood cells are the most common type of blood cell and are responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body. A normal red blood cell count ranges between 4.5 and 5.5 million/uL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] million/uL is below the normal range.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Urobilinogen'){Urobilinogen is a byproduct of the breakdown of hemoglobin in the liver and is excreted in the urine. A normal urobilinogen level is between 0.2 and 1.0 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate liver disease, hemolytic anemia, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Hematocrit'){Hematocrit is a measure of the percentage of red blood cells in the blood. A normal hematocrit level is between 38 and 52% for men and between 35 and 47% for women. A value of [[ValueNo3]]% is not in the normal range and may indicate anemia or blood loss.}elseif(LabelItem2=='MCH'){MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is a measure of the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. A normal MCH level is between 27 and 33 pg. A value of [[ValueNo3]] pg is not in the normal range and may indicate iron deficiency anemia or other medical conditions}elseif(LabelItem2=='Hemoglobin'){Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. A normal hemoglobin level is between 13.5 and 17.5 g/dL for men and between 12.0 and 15.5 g/dL for women. A value of [[ValueNo3]] g/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate anemia or blood loss.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Troponin T'){Troponin T is a protein that is released into the bloodstream when there is damage to the heart muscle. A normal troponin T level is below 0.03 ng/mL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] ng/mL is not in the normal range and may indicate a heart attack or other heart-related conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='pO2'){pO2 is a measure of the pressure of oxygen in arterial blood. A normal pO2 level is between 75 and 100 mmHg. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mmHg is not in the normal range and may indicate lung disease, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)}elseif(LabelItem2=='pH'){pH is a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of the blood. A normal pH level is between 7.35 and 7.45. A value of [[ValueNo3]] is not in the normal range and may indicate respiratory or metabolic acidosis.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Urea Nitrogen'){Urea nitrogen is a waste product that is produced in the liver and excreted by the kidneys. A normal urea nitrogen level is between 7 and 20 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the normal range and may indicate kidney disease or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Neutrophils'){Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that help fight off infections. A normal percentage of neutrophils in the blood is between 40% and 60%. A value of [[ValueNo3]]% is not in the normal range and may indicate an infection, inflammation, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='PT'){PT stands for prothrombin time, which is a blood test that measures the time it takes for blood to clot. A normal PT range is between 11 and 13.5 seconds. A value of [[ValueNo3]] seconds is not in the normal range and may indicate a blood clotting disorder or liver disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Chloride'){Chloride is an electrolyte that helps regulate the balance of fluids and acid-base in the body. A normal chloride level is between 96 and 106 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as vomiting, diarrhea, or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Amylase'){Amylase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas that helps break down carbohydrates. A normal amylase level is between 25 and 125 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate pancreatitis or other pancreatic disorders.}elseif(LabelItem2=='White Blood Cells'){White blood cells are a type of blood cell that help the body fight off infections. A normal range of white blood cells is between 4,000 and 11,000/mm3. A value of [[ValueNo3]]/mm3 is not in the recommended level and may indicate an infection or inflammation.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Magnesium'){Magnesium is a mineral that is important for muscle and nerve function, as well as for maintaining heart health. A normal magnesium level is between 1.8 and 2.4 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may cause certain medical conditions, such as malnutrition, alcoholism, or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Creatinine'){Creatinine is a waste product produced by muscles and is filtered out of the blood by the kidneys. A normal creatinine level is between 0.6 and 1.2 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate kidney dysfunction or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Bicarbonate'){Bicarbonate is an electrolyte that helps regulate the pH of the blood. A normal bicarbonate level is between 22 and 28 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate metabolic acidosis, which can be caused by certain medical conditions, such as kidney disease or diabetes.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Potassium'){Potassium is an electrolyte that is essential for proper muscle and nerve function, as well as for regulating the heartbeat. A normal potassium level is between 3.5 and 5.0 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as kidney disease, vomiting, diarrhea, or the use of certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Calculated Total CO2'){Total CO2 (carbon dioxide) is a measurement of the amount of bicarbonate in the blood, which helps to regulate the body's pH balance. A normal total CO2 level is between 22 and 29 mEq/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mEq/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate respiratory or metabolic acidosis.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Phosphate'){Phosphate is a mineral that is important for bone health, energy production, and many other bodily functions. A normal phosphate level is between 2.5 and 4.5 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as kidney disease, malnutrition, or hyperparathyroidism.}elseif(LabelItem2=='PTT'){PTT (partial thromboplastin time) is a blood test that measures the time it takes for blood to clot. A normal PTT range is typically between 25 and 35 seconds. A value of [[ValueNo3]] seconds is not in the recommended level and may indicate a bleeding disorder or the use of blood-thinning medications.}elseif(LabelItem2=='MCHC'){MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is a measure of the concentration of hemoglobin in the red blood cells. A normal MCHC range is typically between 32 and 36 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] g/dL is not in the recommended level and may indicate anemia or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Lactate Dehydrogenase (LD)'){LD is an enzyme that is found in many organs and tissues in the body. An LD test can help diagnose a variety of medical conditions, such as liver or heart disease, anemia, or cancer. A normal LD level is typically between 105 and 333 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate tissue damage or disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Protein, Total'){Total protein is a measurement of the total amount of protein in the blood. A normal total protein level is between 6.0 and 8.3 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] g/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by a variety of medical conditions, such as liver or kidney disease, malnutrition, or certain cancers.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)'){ALT is an enzyme that is found primarily in the liver. An ALT test can help diagnose liver disease or damage. A normal ALT level is typically between 7 and 56 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate liver disease or damage.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Albumin'){Albumin is a protein produced by the liver and is an important component of blood. A normal albumin level is between 3.4 and 5.4 g/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]]g/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by liver disease, kidney disease, malnutrition, or other medical conditions.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Sodium'){Sodium is an electrolyte that helps regulate the body's fluid balance and is important for normal muscle and nerve function. A normal sodium level is between 135 and 145 mmol/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mmol/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by dehydration, certain medications, or medical conditions such as Addison's disease or kidney disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Platelet Count'){Platelets are blood cells that help with clotting and preventing bleeding. A normal platelet count is between 150,000 and 450,000/mm3. A value of [[ValueNo3]] /mm3 is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as bone marrow disorders, viral infections, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Lipase'){Lipase is an enzyme that helps break down fats in the body. A normal lipase level is between 10 and 140 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as pancreatitis, gallbladder disease, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Alkaline Phosphatase'){Alkaline phosphatase is an enzyme that is important for bone and liver health. A normal alkaline phosphatase level is between 44 and 147 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as liver or bone disease, or certain medications.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Macrophage'){Macrophages are a type of white blood cell that help the body fight infection and inflammation. A normal macrophage percentage is less than 8%. A value of [[ValueNo3]] % or higher may indicate an infection or other medical condition.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Lactate'){Lactate is a waste product produced by the body during exercise or when there is not enough oxygen in the blood. A normal lactate level is less than 2 mmol/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mmol/L is not in the recommended level and may indicate a medical emergency such as sepsis, shock, or heart failure.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Myelocytes'){Myelocytes are immature white blood cells that are produced in the bone marrow. A normal myelocyte percentage is less than 3%. A value of [[ValueNo3]] % or higher may indicate certain medical conditions, such as leukemia or other bone marrow disorders.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Haptoglobin'){Haptoglobin is a protein that helps bind and remove hemoglobin from the blood. A normal haptoglobin level is between 30 and 200 mg/dL. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mg/dL is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as hemolytic anemia or liver disease.}elseif(LabelItem2=='Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST)'){AST is an enzyme that is important for liver and muscle function. A normal AST level is between 10 and 40 U/L. A value of [[ValueNo3]] U/L is not in the recommended level and may be caused by certain medical conditions, such as liver disease or muscle damage.}elseif(LabelItem2=='pCO2'){pCO2 is the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood and is an important indicator of respiratory function. A normal pCO2 level is between 35 and 45 mmHg. A value of [[ValueNo3]] mmHg is not in the recommended level and may indicate respiratory acidosis, which can be caused by conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, or asthma.}else{The test result is inaccurate, due to Instrumental error.}]]
